key_points: Canada's military mission in Afghanistan concluded hours before a deadly attack at Kabul airport.
Suicide bombers targeted crowds at Kabul airport, killing at least 11 American marines and one navy medic.
An unknown number of Canadians and their families remain trapped in Afghanistan post-withdrawal.
The withdrawal aimed to meet the U.S.-led mission's deadline of August 31.
Canadian Forces confirmed all Canadian military personnel involved in the withdrawal are safe and accounted for.
Over 47,000 Afghan civilians and more than 66,000 Afghan military and police died in the war.
Gen. Wayne Eyre acknowledged the unpredictability of warfare and the rapid Taliban takeover.
Canada evacuated approximately 3,700 people from Afghanistan.
Gen. Kenneth McKenzie highlighted the real threat of ISIS and continued evacuation efforts despite the attacks.
The U.S. attributes the attacks to ISIS-K, with the expectation of further attacks.
spokespersons: Gen. Wayne Eyre (Acting Chief of the Defence Staff)
Gen. Kenneth McKenzie (Commander of U.S. Central Command)
